Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "BSD-3-Clause with uncommon placeholders?" (#9344) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Discussed in https://github.com/NuGet/Home/discussions/12349
Originally posted by **wismann** January 7, 2023 I just checked the NuGet provided BSD-3-Clause license against the version from spdx.org https://licenses.nuget.org/BSD-3-Clause https://spdx.org/licenses/BSD-3-Clause.html Notable differences: 1. SPDX: > 3. Neither the name of the copyright holder nor the names of its contributors may be used to endorse or promote [...] NuGet: > 3. _____ be used to endorse or promote [...] I think the generic wording is common and sufficient. There is no way on earth to fill this blank implicitly. 2. SPDX: > THIS SOFTWARE IS PROVIDED BY THE COPYRIGHT HOLDERS AND CONTRIBUTORS "AS IS" [...] > IN NO EVENT SHALL THE COPYRIGHT OWNER OR CONTRIBUTORS BE LIABLE [...] NuGet: > THIS SOFTWARE IS PROVIDED BY _____ "AS IS" [...] > IN NO EVENT SHALL _____ BE LIABLE [...] I think the generic wording is common and sufficient. No need for placeholders. 3. SPDX: > [...] AND ANY EXPRESS OR IMPLIED WARRANTIES, INCLUDING, BUT NOT LIMITED TO, THE IMPLIED WARRANTIES [...] NuGet: > [...] AND ANY _____ OR IMPLIED WARRANTIES, INCLUDING, BUT NOT LIMITED TO, THE IMPLIED WARRANTIES [...] This placeholder does not make any sense to me. Questions: 1. What is the source for the NuGet version of this license? 2. Is it necessary and/or advised to differ with the license text from most other sources?

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "The alternative package cannot be found through clicking the link in deprecated package info" (#9399) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

Visual Studio Package Management UI

### Product Version

NuGet Client Dev\6.6.0.27

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

It's more difficult to complete my work

### Repro Steps & Context

#### Repro Steps:    

1. Create a C# Console App (.Net Core 7.0) project.  

2. Right-click the project in Solution Explorer and select "Manage NuGet Packages…" menu item to open PM UI.  

3. Click the settings button, add a deprecated package source https://apidev.nugettest.org/v3-index/index.json and click “OK” button. 

4. Select the deprecated package source and go to "Browse" tab. 

5. Search for a deprecated package "Test10K" in "Browse" tab. 

6. Click the link “affine” under the description of the package “Test10K” or the link “afine” on the right panel. 

#### Expected:    

The alternative package “afine” is showing in the searched package list. 

#### Actual:    

The alternative package “afine” cannot be found through clicking the link in deprecated package info as below screenshot: 
![MicrosoftTeams-image (8)](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/84695155/220860029-a2547789-0b52-4854-82ee-258524c61eb6.png)

#### Notes: 

1.The alternative package can be shown by searching the package name “affine” in “Browse" tab as below screenshot: 
![MicrosoftTeams-image (9)](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/84695155/220860241-d6dd8ebc-ab0d-4db6-bee9-3c80e55663fb.png)
2. It's doesn't repro on VS Main\33419.19 + NuGet Client Dev\6.6.0.24.


### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Opened issue "Confusing error message for -MSBuildPath argument in the English resource file of the Nuget.CommandLine client." (#12461) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

NuGet.exe

### Product Version

nuget.exe v.6.4.0.123

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

It bothers me. A fix would be nice

### Repro Steps & Context

Description:
When the -MsBuildPath doesn't exist the command line returns an error saying that the directory "doesn't not exist". Which is confusing since the error stems from a Directory.Exists() == false check. 

Reproduce:
1. Execute the restore command and specify an non-existent path in the -MSBuildPath argument

Expected:
A well formed sentence explaining that the path does not exists

Actual:
The sentence returned contains the double negative "doesn't not exist"

### Verbose Logs

```shell
nuget.exe restore testProject.sln -MsBuildPath 'c:\some_non_existent_path'
Using Msbuild from 'c:\some_non_existent_path'
MSBuildPath : c:\some_non_existent_path doesn't not exist.
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Signing:  raise actionable message on Linux if verification results in untrusted failure" (#12459) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
When signed package verification fails on Linux, we should raise an actionable message with a link to a document that explains https://github.com/dotnet/designs/blob/main/accepted/2021/signed-package-verification/re-enable-signed-package-verification-technical.md#linux and how to curate a sufficiently complete certificate bundle.

CC @aortiz-msft

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Run .NET SDK tests against .NET vNext" (#12458) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
We should take existing .NET SDK tests and enable them to run in a separate, nightly pipeline that targets .NET vNext.  So, while the other pipelines target test [latest .NET 7.0 SDK](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/3e0df127a764994dd5de2e33f3b278c0da0d1081/build/config.props#L47), the new pipeline would test latest .NET 8.0 SDK.

CC @aortiz-msft

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "dotnet nuget hangs when ran as non-root user" (#12457) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

NuGet SDK

### Product Version

dotnet sdk 6.0.405

### Worked before?

dotnet sdk 3.1.426

### Impact

I'm unable to use this version

### Repro Steps & Context

Running Amazon Linux 2

### Working
As a root user:
```
> whoami
root
```
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/119940912/221855129-86d76848-7bc4-4bdd-a590-ccf27f58bd16.png)

Check if dotnet is available, which works:
```
> dotnet --version
6.0.405
```

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/119940912/221855217-339c2e99-9c51-4d46-a569-ec8bbfde6adc.png)

Simply run dotnet nuget to check if its available, which it does 
```
> dotnet nuget
NuGet Command Line 6.3.1.1

Usage: dotnet nuget [options] [command]

Options:
  -h|--help  Show help information
  --version  Show version information

Commands:
  add      Add a NuGet source.
  delete   Deletes a package from the server.
  disable  Disable a NuGet source.
  enable   Enable a NuGet source.
  list     List configured NuGet sources.
  locals   Clears or lists local NuGet resources such as http requests cache, packages folder, plugin operations cache  or machine-wide global packages folder.
  push     Pushes a package to the server and publishes it.
  remove   Remove a NuGet source.
  sign     Signs NuGet package(s) at <package-paths> with the specified certificate.
  trust    Manage the trusted signers.
  update   Update a NuGet source.
  verify   Verifies a signed NuGet package.

Use "dotnet nuget [command] --help" for more information about a command.
```

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/119940912/221855314-1c7da2de-c60d-4020-8b56-b7216fb198f2.png)


### Not Working:
As a non-root user -Check if dotnet is available, which works:
```
> dotnet --version
6.0.405
```
As a non-root user - dotnet nuget, and it will hang indefinitely 
```
> dotnet nuget
```
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/119940912/221852545-df038a2f-37e3-46de-882c-9e860e9a9559.png)

If ran as a background task, it will max the CPU out at 100%
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/119940912/221853038-742a6710-e2a1-4860-b533-ed447a9bc5ab.png)

The non-root user, has ownership of the /usr/share/dotnet/ folder and all files within it, user name blurred out but it is the users name and group.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/119940912/221853591-2fa8995c-1ea1-4ee8-9fe3-8b22908a7383.png)

### Conclusion
After we added dotnet 6 to our servers, any dotnet nuget commands are hanging, we have the following versions installed:
```
2.1.818 [/usr/share/dotnet/sdk]
3.1.426 [/usr/share/dotnet/sdk]
6.0.405 [/usr/share/dotnet/sdk]
```

From what I can see this looks like a permission issue but all relevant directory and files are owned by the non-root user so I am not sure what else to do.

### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Reopened issue "Trim the input in the search box for “Installed” and “Updates” tab" (#12030) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

NuGet.exe

### Product Version

Dev\6.4.0.47

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

It bothers me. A fix would be nice

### Repro Steps & Context

## Installation steps: 
1. Install VS Main\32916.354 from: [Pipelines - Run main-32816.354 (visualstudio.com)](https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_build/results?buildId=6568078&view=ms.vss-build-web.run-extensions-tab)
2. Install NuGet Client Dev\6.4.0.47 from: [Pipelines - Run 6.4.0.47 (visualstudio.com)](https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_build/results?buildId=6565718&view=results)

## Repro steps: 
1. Create a C# Class Library (.Net Core) project.
2. Build the solution and make sure compilation succeeds. 
3. Right-click the project in Solution Explorer and select “Manage NuGet Packages…” menu item to open PM UI. 
4. Click “Browse” tab and select the “nuget.org” from Package source drop-down list.
5. Search 'Microsoft.NETCore.Platforms' package in the filter of “Browse” tab, select version 6.0.1 in the “Version” drop-down box and click the ‘Install’ button on the right panel.
6. Switch to the “Installed” and “Updates” tab. 

## Expected:
The package should show on “Installed” and “Updates” tab.

## Actual:
No package found on “Installed” and “Updates” tab as below screenshot.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/40230425/185071172-4cbec8fd-c9d4-4866-8f38-75a584101745.png)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/40230425/185071257-e8b19b43-fc76-4ccf-bb1a-d0ea9dcf38a6.png)

## Note:
The issue reproes when the project is first created.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Visual Studio ignoring CPM opt-out when ManagePackageVersionsCentrally is false but Directory.Packages.props exists" (#12359) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

Visual Studio Package Management UI

### Product Version

VS 2022 Enterprise 17.4.3

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

It's more difficult to complete my work

### Repro Steps & Context

Consider a repository with the following structure:

```
- Directory.Packages.props
- src/
  - Directory.Packages.props
  - solution.sln
  - project/
    - project.csproj
 ```

- The top-level `Directory.Packages.props` opts into central package management (`<ManagePackageVersionsCentrally>true</ManagePackageVersionsCentrally>`). 
- The nested `Directory.Packages.props` file in the `src` folder opts out of central package management (`<ManagePackageVersionsCentrally>false</ManagePackageVersionsCentrally>`). 
- When `solution.sln` is opened in Visual Studio and you add a package reference to the project via the VS Package Manager UI, the project reference in the project file is added without a version and a package version is added to the nested `Directory.Packages.props` instead, even though the closest `Directory.Packages.props` file to the solution has opted out of central package management.

Steps to reproduce:

1. Download and unzip the attached file: [cpm_issue.zip](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/files/10393156/cpm_issue.zip)
2. Open the solution file in Visual Studio.
3. Add a NuGet package reference to the project via the Package Manager UI.

Workaround is to manually enter or update package references in the project file instead of using the UI.


### Verbose Logs

_No response_

1. Install VS Main\32916.354 from: [Pipelines - Run main-32816.354 (visualstudio.com)](https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_build/results?buildId=6568078&view=ms.vss-build-web.run-extensions-tab)
2. Install NuGet Client Dev\6.4.0.47 from: [Pipelines - Run 6.4.0.47 (visualstudio.com)](https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_build/results?buildId=6565718&view=results)

## Repro steps: 
1. Create a C# Class Library (.Net Core) project.
2. Build the solution and make sure compilation succeeds. 
3. Right-click the project in Solution Explorer and select “Manage NuGet Packages…” menu item to open PM UI. 
4. Click “Browse” tab and select the “nuget.org” from Package source drop-down list.
5. Search 'Microsoft.NETCore.Platforms' package in the filter of “Browse” tab, select version 6.0.1 in the “Version” drop-down box and click the ‘Install’ button on the right panel.
6. Switch to the “Installed” and “Updates” tab. 

## Expected:
The package should show on “Installed” and “Updates” tab.

## Actual:
No package found on “Installed” and “Updates” tab as below screenshot.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/40230425/185071172-4cbec8fd-c9d4-4866-8f38-75a584101745.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/40230425/185071225-2798c0d8-0c1e-49af-898b-482ac0773290.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/40230425/185071257-e8b19b43-fc76-4ccf-bb1a-d0ea9dcf38a6.png)

## Note:
The issue reproes when the project is first created.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Moving to the new .NET Foundation CLA service" (#68) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
Hello everyone
The .NET Foundation is transitioning to a new CLA service and I'm posting here to let you know it's happening. Some background info:

The new CLA service is based off of https://github.com/microsoft/ContributorLicenseAgreement, except it uses the dotnet-policy-service app

- Current contributors do not need to sign the CLA again
- The CLA agreement itself is not changing
- As part of the install/configuration process, the following work items will be completed

1. Create a .github repo if it doesn't exist already
2. Install the dotnet-policy-service app
3. Create PRs for the platformcontext.xml and cla.yml files
4. Disable the existing CLA webhook
5. Push the PRs to enable the new CLA service

That's all there is to it. I'll update this issue once the work is complete

Thanks
Chris
.NET Foundation Operations team

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "NuGet.org migration towards a new multi-CDN infrastructure" (#60) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
In the coming weeks, nuget.org will be migrating towards a new multi-CDN infrastructure that will improve the experience of our users. This change allows our team flexibility to switch to a back-up provider in the case that one CDN is down, which will broaden coverage for our users.

Some changes are coming for older TLS cipher suites, which may result in connectivity issues. From our data we believe this will affect only a small percentage of requests. We will be monitoring all feedback channels during the migration to assess impact and adjust our roll-out timeline as needed.

Below, we provide resources to determine whether you will be affected by this change. This utilizes the [.NET CLI](https://dotnet.microsoft.com/) to install a package from our pre-production (INT) environment which tests connectivity:


```
mkdir cdn-test
cd cdn-test
dotnet new classlib
dotnet add package BaseTestPackage.NetStandard --source https://apiint.nugettest.org/v3/index.json
```

If you are experiencing connectivity issues while connecting to nuget.org or restoring packages from https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json, such as:

"The SSL connection could not be established"

Please ensure that TLS 1.2 and any of the following cipher suites have been enabled on your machine:

TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_256_GCM_SHA384
TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256
TLS_DHE_RSA_WITH_AES_256_GCM_SHA384
TLS_DHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256

If you have any questions, do reach out to us at support@nuget.org or by commenting on the discussion issue: NuGet/Home#11058
